replies.msg:
各位大英帝國做緊嘢／將會做嘢嘅巴絲打，歡迎入嚟呢到鳩噏扮下工

Q&A credit to 滑蛋豬仔飯

Q: 如果無BC又想係英國打工係咪好難?

A:
通常會比working visa一係大公司
D細公司仔都見過有批不過當然會少D

老老實實渣BNO/特區係就係難D不過都唔係無可能
都識得有人搞得掂個visa
以前有同學會係cv度寫明話要working visa
如果間公司都肯in你既話多數即係肯批
唔洗浪費大家時間
大小公司都有 試下無妨

再唔係學其他巴打講
申請左working holiday做住先都未嘗不可
當然之後整唔整到tier 2 working visa就唔敢講
不過起碼都有2年比你係度做下野儲下經驗先

如果做開比較專業行業既朋友其實拎左working holiday visa先，再轉tier 2既機會都幾樂觀，都識幾個朋友都係咁，好似都係做design / I.T.之類 (by 賽麗娜Serena)


Q: 想問下英國見工係咪同香港一樣都係上網報?

A:
如果你話搵工過程其實同香港差唔多
睇你咩工啦
普通黎講大公司既話都係cv cover letter -> online test -> phone in-> assessment centre ( 可以好多round) -> final in
細公司就少幾個步驟咁


Q: 想問下係咪bno 同特區都可以fg 一年tier5 先，唔洗特登要搵肯比tier2 既公司住

A:
你英國畢業定香港想過去？ 唔係英國畢業唔肯定當地申請有無唔同但BNO 隨時可以申請tier 5 重有兩年，特區要抽架，都係兩年。
當地申請可能短d , 我當初因爲公司未令到可以簽visa 既licence 就幫我申請住tier 5 先，得特區又過左抽籤所以係visa 公司幫我係英國申請，但咁就得一年.. 無深究點解。
但全部香港申請過去既都有兩年。 (by 花生哥)

Q: 下年打算去working holiday 會唔會好難搵工同搵地方住（想住反係zoom1,2) 聽人講就話最好係香港搵定先去係好定唔好 我就做開酒吧個邊會唔會香港人 真心求教

A:
英國bar tender既需求量其實好大 因為佢pub既數量基本上同香港7仔有得揮 甚至係正常既餐廳入面都會有間pub仔/bar比人淨飲野吹水
所以你有經驗根本唔洗驚 去到英國任何一個地方都一定搵到野做

講我自己經驗啦 我就做好typical既西餐廳既 入面全部鬼佬
因為要升supervisor 所以gm要求我識哂餐廳所有部份 包括floor hatch同bar
Bar嗰邊我完全係一張白紙 連用咖啡機都唔識 基本上淨係識開水喉倒果汁呢d白痴都識做既野
去到依家講緊一個在既時間 叫做忙起上黎可以打哂三邊 聽日冇人返比人編左去自己睇bar

我覺得做bar最緊要係識同客吹水 尤其係餐廳bar
好似我地咁 係住宅區 長期都有熟客日日黎打"等" 真係日日風雨不改黎報到
黎到冇野做咪同bar tender吹水囉 所以你一定要好吹得

其餘都冇乜野擔心 驚咪去indeed search下囉 一大炸請緊人 (by 小野屋杏)

Q: 英國黎緊暑假畢業，準備搵工 （宜家4月中係咪太遲)

A: 唔遲
雖然有啲係截左
但仲有好多
留學生有優勢 就係唔怕relocation
成個英國既工你都apply得
宜家真係開始send cv都唔會太遲既
好多大公司如果唔係grad scheme既話其實一路都請緊人
以前好多同學都係8/9月先有offer
有D直頭下年1月先有工開
所以唔洗擔心既肯踏出第一步搵工就ok (by 馬壯FN2)

Which passport she will use for her UK visa application? BN(O) or HKSAR?

BNO


If you are using your BN(O) passport for UK residence visa (greater than 6 months), you will be able to register to vote in all UK elections as a Commonwealth citizen. Being on the electoral roll helps you to build up your own credit history in the UK.

Once you get Indefinite Leave to Remain (ILR) - as a BN(O) passport holder, you can apply for British civil service jobs as a Commonwealth citizen.

Also remember that you can register to become a British Citizen using form B(OTA) as a BN(O) passport holder a year after ILR. Registration is a cheaper method then naturalisation.

According to the Home Office document below -

https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/525708/Appendix_FM_1_7_Financial_Requirement.pdf

you can calculate whether you meet the UK spouse visa financial requirement by adding up the gross pay you receive from the six monthly payslips and then divided by 6 for the average. Multiply the average gross wage by 12 to see whether you meet the spouse financial requirement. Please see section 5 (especially section 5.1.4.) for details.

Congratulations!

If you are getting marry in Hong Kong later this year, you will get a marriage certificate. As Hong Kong marriage certificate is in both Chinese and English, you will not need to translate the certificate into English for the UK spouse visa application.

Some points -

1) Get a few of your and your future wife's own Certify Birth / Marriage certificate from the Hong Kong Immigration department while you are in Hong Kong. You don't want to fly back to Hong Kong to get them!

http://www.immd.gov.hk/eng/services/birth-death/Application_for_Search_of_Birth_Records_and_Certified_Copy_of_Birth_Entry.html

http://www.immd.gov.hk/eng/services/marriage/Certificate_of_Absence_of_Marriage_records.html

2) Remember to take some photos of your big day (both with yourselves and the happy couple with relatives) and put some in the spouse visa application for the Entry Clearance Officer to see.

3) Have you think of making records of the communications between you and your future wife for the spouse visa application?

4) Your future wife should start learning to drive and aiming to get her Hong Kong driving licence before coming to the UK if not already done so. A Hong Kong driving licence gained by a driving test in Hong Kong can be exchange to an UK driving licence without test.

5) Banking - she should be thinking of opening an UK bank account in Hong Kong before coming to the UK with either the Bank of East Asia or HSBC.

https://www.hkbea.com/html/en/bea-international-services-services.html

https://www.hsbc.com.hk/personal/hsbc-premier/features/premier-overseas-account.html

Sorry for the long post - hope the above is helpful.

To Das brother. Are u BC or tier-2 visa?

Coz im hving similar case to you. I will start my work in end of September and would like to know what is the criteria to apply my future wife to get the tier-2 woring visa.

I was born in the UK so I'm holding BC

I remember you need either proof of saving or your company sponsoring both you and your wife.

Each dependant must have £630 available to them whether they apply with you or separately. This is in addition to the £945 you must have to support yourself.

You must have proof you have the money, and that it’s been in your bank account or your dependant’s bank account for at least 90 days before the application


you can check if you company is on the list of registered sponsor

1 - Good for you. Make sure you get an extra certify copy of your marriage certificate from the Hong Kong Immigration Department.

2 - re photos - need to send some photos of you two together for her visa application. You don't need a lot of photos, but enough to cover the time line from the start of the relationship to the wedding and post wedding stage.

3 - should be fine.

4 - My view is that it would be better for she can learn how o drive in her own native language first. You can get her to do lessons on the basics in Hong Kong before coming over to the UK.

5 - Keep her bank account in Hong Kong. It is not that easy for someone to open a bank account in Hong Kong now. If her Hang Seng bank account is only a HK$ passbook account, she may want to open a foreign currency bank account with Hang Seng bank as well (this would enable her to deposit GBP £). She may want to open an UK bank account in Hong Kong before she leaves, but it is up to her.

Are you holding Tier 2 (General)? If so, the link below will give you some information on how to apply for a Tier 2 (General) dependent visa.

https://www.gov.uk/tier-2-general/family-members

One more thing - if you are planning to have children and want the children to have Hong Kong ID cards and Chinese nationality, it would best for you to have them before you get Indefinite Leave to Remain (ILR) in the UK. Once you got ILR, your children born in the UK will be automatically become British Citizens, thus unable to get Chinese nationality and Hong Kong ID card.

If you are not married to your partner, you will need to have documentary evidence to the Home Office to show that you two have been 'living together in a relationship similar to marriage or civil partnership for a period of at least 2 years'. (Immigration rule 319C (c)(iii))

https://www.gov.uk/guidance/immigration-rules/immigration-rules-part-8-family-members

If you two are planning to get marry anyway - would it not be better to move this forward to make the visa application process easier?

So if i would like my children get both Hong Kong ID and british citizen.. he/she shld be born in UK first and apply Hong Kong ID before I obtain the ILR (Which is 5 yrs). And once I got ILR, My children willl get both Hong Kong and British Citizen, is it correct?


A baby born in the UK does not automatically receive British Citizenship. The British born baby will get British Citizenship if at lease one of the parent is -

1) a British Citizen OR
2) have Indefinite Leave to Remain (ILR) in the UK

As Chinese nationality law does not allow dual nationality for Chinese nationals, in order to get Chinese nationality for a child born in the UK, you need to show that you and your wife only have limited leave to remain in the UK. Therefore, as long as your child is born before you or your wife gets ILR or British Citizenship, then the baby will be a Chinese national as he/she has no other nationality.

If you are planning to have children and want your children to have both British Citizenship and Chinese nationality (thus Hong Kong ID card), here are a few ways for you to consider -

1) Have the child in the UK before you or your wife gets ILR. This means that the child, although born in the UK, is not a British Citizen. An important point is to apply for the baby's HKSAR passport as soon as possible at one of the Chinese consulate in the UK. The baby is Chinese and will need to apply for registration to become a British Citizen using form MN1 under section 1(3) of the British Nationality Act 1981.

2) Have the child in Hong Kong before either you or your wife gets ILR - the baby will have Chinese nationality. However, you will need to get a visa for the child in order for him/her to come and live in the UK.

3) Have the child in Hong Kong after either you or your wife gets British Citizenship. Your child is a Chinese national as he/she is born in Hong Kong and he/she is also a British Citizen by descent. You will need to apply for a British passport for the child in order for him/her to come and live in the UK. Please note that a British Citizen by descent cannot automatically pass on his/her British Citizenship to his/her child (i.e. your grandchild) born outside of the UK.

Sorry for the long post - hope it is helpful.

Some forward planning for your future wife -

1) Renew her BN(O) passport if she has that status.

2) Pass her Hong Kong driving test and get a Hong Kong driving licence. A Hong Kong driving licence gained by a driving test in Hong Kong can be exchange to an UK one without test.

3) Open an UK bank account in Hong Kong before coming over to the UK. Both Bank of East Asia and HSBC offer this service.

https://www.hkbea.com/html/en/bea-international-services-services.html

https://www.hsbc.com.hk/personal/hsbc-premier/features/premier-overseas-account.html

3) Have the child in Hong Kong after either you or your wife gets British Citizenship. Your child is a Chinese national as he/she is born in Hong Kong and he/she is also a British Citizen by descent. You will need to apply for a British passport for the child in order for him/her to come and live in the UK. Please note that a British Citizen by
descent cannot automatically pass on his/her British Citizenship to his/her child (i.e. your grandchild) born outside of the UK.

Sorry for the long post - hope it is helpful.


Many thanks to your point in details

Seems like option 1 is best way to let the child be BC and also let my grandchild be BC even born outside of the UK. And I will plan to get marry asap to make the visa process easier.


Get married in Hong Kong - as Hong Kong's wedding certificates are in both Chinese and English language, you will not need to translate it into English for UK visa applications.

Option 1 can be done before either you or your wife gets ILR. Remember to look into registering the UK born child as a British Citizen using form MN1.

Another point - get your future wife to renew her BN(O) passport (if she has not already done so) and use it for her UK visa application.

搭單問

If different visas and passports (i.e. HKSAR+BNO) are used, and given the combined duration of all visas is exactly 10 years, would the 10 years' residence requirement for the ILR be satisfied in this case?


I would not think this matters as long as the details within the two passport are the same (for example name, date and place of birth).

I would suggest you to fill in your BN(O) passport's details in the SET (O) form so that the Indefinite Leave to Remain will be issue to your BN(O) passport and you can take advantage of being able to register as a British Citizen using form B(OTA) - which is a cheaper way than naturalisation using form AN.

https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/application-to-register-as-a-british-citizen-form-bota

Remember to get your UK Tier 2 visa using your BN(O) passport if you are entitle to one.

Using a BN(O) passport have the following advantages over HKSAR passport -

1) BN(O) passport holders can register to vote in all UK elections. Being on the electoral roll helps you to build up your own credit history in the UK. HKSAR passport holders are not entitle to vote in the UK.

2) HKSAR passport holders, as Chinese nationals are required to register with the local police in the UK while BN(O) passport holders don't need to register.

3) Once a BN(O) passport holder get Indefinite Leave to Remain (ILR - 永久居留) in the UK, he/she can apply for some British civil service jobs as a Commonwealth citizen. HKSAR passport holders cannot apply for British civil service jobs until he/she gets British Citizenship.

4) BN(O) passport holders are entitle to get British Citizenship via registration using form B(OTA), which is a cheaper way than naturalisation. (£1163 for registration vs £1282 for naturalisation - both 2017 prices).

You can also exchange your Hong Kong driving licence to an UK one without test as long as you gained your Hong Kong driving licence by a driving test in Hong Kong.

Remember to get your UK Tier 2 visa using your BN(O) passport if you are entitle to one.

Using a BN(O) passport have the following advantages over HKSAR passport -

1) BN(O) passport holders can register to vote in all UK elections. Being on the electoral roll helps you to build up your own credit history in the UK. HKSAR passport holders are not entitle to vote in the UK.

2) HKSAR passport holders, as Chinese nationals are required to register with the local police in the UK while BN(O) passport holders don't need to register.

3) Once a BN(O) passport holder get Indefinite Leave to Remain (ILR - 永久居留) in the UK, he/she can apply for some British civil service jobs as a Commonwealth citizen. HKSAR passport holders cannot apply for British civil service jobs until he/she gets British Citizenship.

4) BN(O) passport holders are entitle to get British Citizenship via registration using form B(OTA), which is a cheaper way than naturalisation. (£1163 for registration vs £1282 for naturalisation - both 2017 prices).

You can also exchange your Hong Kong driving licence to an UK one without test as long as you gained your Hong Kong driving licence by a driving test in Hong Kong.

As you said in other post that the boss in the UK is on holiday just now, you could still have enough time to renew your expired BN(O) passport before applying for your UK Tier 2 visa. As long as you have your expired BN(O) passport, it is not going to take long to renew. You can use the link before to renew your BN(O) passport -

https://www.gov.uk/overseas-passports

You may not have any plans to come to the UK, but now as an opportunity comes, you should take it. Remember to make British Citizenship as your goal - don't return to Hong Kong with only Indefinite Leave to Remain (永久居留權). Indefinite Leave to Remain status will be revoked if the holder lives outside of the UK for more than 2 years.

東網透視：憑一支單簧管　香港仔入選御林軍

http://hk.on.cc/hk/bkn/cnt/news/20170812/bkn-20170812093047180-0812_00822_001.html

以香港第一人身份成爲英國御林軍樂手，David憶述，源於幾年前一次聚餐時偶遇英國陸軍音樂總監，對方提起英國御林軍樂隊招募新隊員，他持有英國國民(海外)護照(BNO)身份也可參與招聘考試，故決定一試。軍樂隊考試分兩部分，體能為先，音樂第二。對於當年33歲的他來說，體能測試是極大的挑戰，要10分半鐘內跑完2.4公里，亦要做掌上壓及仰臥起坐，首輪面試因跑步不達標而失敗。但他並沒有放棄，返港苦操3、4個月後再接受挑戰，2013年過關斬將通過所有測試，成功取錄。

身為英皇室的御林軍，薪酬福利令人關注，David則不予透露，僅指薪金水平較香港警察低一些，除普通的醫療和交通福利外，最優厚是住房福利，他與同事在倫敦市中心合住一間800至900平方呎單位，月租只需30英鎊，僅相當於300港元，相信令不少香港青年人羨慕。他現長居英國，還有一年便可入籍，目標是繼續在軍隊攀升，成爲終身職業。

Don't understand why Chinese people are so interested in other people's salaries'. The journalist should do a bit more homework -

http://www.army.mod.uk/documents/general/Ratesofpay-Regular.pdf

An Army soldier gets £18,488 per year.

身為英皇室的御林軍，薪酬福利令人關注，David則不予透露，僅指薪金水平較香港警察低一些，除普通的醫療和交通福利外，最優厚是住房福利，他與同事在倫敦市中心合住一間800至900平方呎單位，月租只需30英鎊，僅相當於300港元，相信令不少香港青年人羨慕。他現長居英國，還有一年便可入籍，目標是繼續在軍隊攀升，成爲終身職業。

You will need to meet the minimum earnings threshold of £35,000 per year if you want to apply for Indefinite Leave to Remain in the UK after 5 years in the UK under a Tier 2 visa. However, the follow exemptions are allowed -

(i) appears on the list of PhD-level occupation codes as stated in the codes of practice in Appendix J,
(ii) appears on the Shortage Occupation List in Appendix K,
(iii) previously appeared on the Shortage Occupation List, as shown by Tables 3 and 4 in Appendix K, at any time when the applicant:
(1) had leave as a Tier 2 (General) Migrant, in which he was sponsored for the applicable job, either with the same or a different employer, during the continuous 6-year period ending on the date of application for indefinite leave to remain, or
(2) was assigned a Certificate of Sponsorship for that job, either with the same or a different employer, which led to a grant of leave as a Tier 2 (General) Migrant during the continuous 6-year period ending on the date of application for indefinite leave to remain.

(Source - Immigration rules 245HF (f) )

https://www.gov.uk/guidance/immigration-rules/immigration-rules-part-6a-the-points-based-system

According to Immigration Rule 245HF (d) (vi) -

(vi) be at least:
(1) £35,000 if the date of application is on or after 6 April 2016,
(2) £35,500 if the date of application is on or after 6 April 2018,
(3) £35,800 if the date of application is on or after 6 April 2019,
(4) £36,200 if the date of application is on or after 6 April 2020,
(5) £36,900 if the date of application is on or after 6 April 2021,
(6) £37,900 if the date of application is on or after 6 April 2022,

https://www.gov.uk/guidance/immigration-rules/immigration-rules-part-6a-the-points-based-system

The current minimum earnings threshold for Indefinite Leave to Remain in the UK is £35,000 p.a. and it will go up to £35,500 p.a. on 6 April 2018.

The figures noted above are the minimum earnings threshold you need to earn if you want to apply for Indefinite Leave to Remain (ILR) after 5 years in the UK under Tier 2.

Example -

If you spent 5 years in the UK under a Tier 2 visa on the 30 June 2020 and you apply for ILR, the minimum earning threshold you need will be £36,200 per year.

As I said in another post that there are exemptions to the minimum earning threshold for Tier 2 visa holders' ILR applications.

As I said in another post that there are exemptions to the minimum earning threshold for Tier 2 visa holders' ILR applications.


What the...


All I can say is that obtaining Indefinite Leave to Remain in the UK is not getting any easier!


If I have no concern on the salary requirements, any other requirement to fulfil?



Here is the list of conditions you need to meet in order to get Indefinite Leave to Remain -

1) you have a Tier 2 (General) visa

2) you’ve been living and working in the UK for 5 years and spent no more than 180 days outside the UK in any 12 months (‘continuous residence’)

3) your employer (sponsor) still needs you for your job - they’ll need to provide a document confirming this

4) your job pays £35,000 or more (unless you’re exempt from the ‘minimum earnings threshold’)

5) you get paid the relevant salary listed in the Codes of Practice

6) Pass the 'Life in the UK' test

7) Pass English language test

According to Immigration Rule 245HF (d) (vi) -

(vi) be at least:
(1) £35,000 if the date of application is on or after 6 April 2016,
(2) £35,500 if the date of application is on or after 6 April 2018,
(3) £35,800 if the date of application is on or after 6 April 2019,
(4) £36,200 if the date of application is on or after 6 April 2020,
(5) £36,900 if the date of application is on or after 6 April 2021,
(6) £37,900 if the date of application is on or after 6 April 2022,

https://www.gov.uk/guidance/immigration-rules/immigration-rules-part-6a-the-points-based-system

The current minimum earnings threshold for Indefinite Leave to Remain in the UK is £35,000 p.a. and it will go up to £35,500 p.a. on 6 April 2018.

what 7 is COS


COS - Certificate of Sponsorship

COS is issued by the Hong Kong Labour Department. As there is an annual quota of 1,000 HKSAR passport holders allowed to get an UK Tier 5 Working Holiday Visa, COS is an administrative way to put the quota in place. This is done by the Hong Kong Labour Department who will only issue 1,000 COS per year and the Home Office making COS a requirement for HKSAR passport holders wanting to get an UK Tier 5 Working Holiday Visa.

BN(O) passport holders do not require a COS when applying for an UK Tier 5 Working Holiday Visa as they are not subject to the 1,000 quota for HKSAR passport holders.

You can save income tax and NI contribution as the company pension money is taken before tax. This will 'reduce' your taxable income.

The same thing happens in a private pension. The UK government will add the basic rate of income tax back to your private pension scheme - so you will get £100 in your private pension when you paid £80. For those who are on the higher rate of income tax, you will need to apply to get the higher rate back from the HMRC.

https://www.gov.uk/tax-on-your-private-pension/pension-tax-relief

You can go for the stakeholder pension -

https://www.pensionsadvisoryservice.org.uk/about-pensions/pensions-basics/contract-based-schemes/stakeholder-pension-schemes?moreInfo=4

The conditions that a stakeholder pension scheme must meet include:

Membership must be available to all employees with a particular employer. It cannot be restricted to certain classes or employees;

Annual management charges must not be more than 1.5% per year for the first ten years of scheme membership and then not more than 1% thereafter;

The minimum gross contribution payable to the scheme must not be set at a level higher than £20, whether the contribution is paid on a regular, or, a one-off basis;

Contributions must be accepted if they are made from a bank account or building society account by way of cheque, direct debit, standing order or direct credit. The provider may also decide to accept other payment methods;

Contributions may be stopped or restarted at any time, without penalty;
Members must be provided with a default fund for investment if they do not want to make investment choices themselves;

Other investment choices offered must meet diversification and suitability criteria;

A ‘lifestyling’ investment option must be available. Lifestyling involves the gradual transfer from higher risk investments to lower risk investments as a member approaches their selected retirement date. Lifestyling must commence at least 5 years before the member’s selected retirement date. It’s designed to shield the member’s accumulated fund from investment volatility in the period leading up to the member’s selected retirement date;

Transfers in from other UK schemes must be accepted without additional charges (including contracted-out benefits);

Normally when a transfer out is made to another scheme, there will not be a penalty. Penalties may apply if an individual is invested in a with-profits fund;

Members must be provided with a detailed statement each year.

Employers don't need to contribute to your pension if your income is low -

Your employer doesn’t have to contribute to your pension if you earn less than:

£490 per month

You can save income tax and NI contribution as the company pension money is taken before tax. This will 'reduce' your taxable income.

The same thing happens in a private pension. You can go for the stakeholder pension -

https://www.pensionsadvisoryservice.org.uk/about-pensions/pensions-basics/contract-based-schemes/stakeholder-pension-schemes?moreInfo=4

The conditions that a stakeholder pension scheme must meet include:

Membership must be available to all employees with a particular employer. It cannot be restricted to certain classes or employees;

Annual management charges must not be more than 1.5% per year for the first ten years of scheme membership and then not more than 1% thereafter;

The minimum gross contribution payable to the scheme must not be set at a level higher than £20, whether the contribution is paid on a regular, or, a one-off basis;

Contributions must be accepted if they are made from a bank account or building society account by way of cheque, direct debit, standing order or direct credit. The provider may also decide to accept other payment methods;

Contributions may be stopped or restarted at any time, without penalty;
Members must be provided with a default fund for investment if they do not want to make investment choices themselves;

Other investment choices offered must meet diversification and suitability criteria;

A ‘lifestyling’ investment option must be available. Lifestyling involves the gradual transfer from higher risk investments to lower risk investments as a member approaches their selected retirement date. Lifestyling must commence at least 5 years before the member’s selected retirement date. It’s designed to shield the member’s accumulated fund from investment volatility in the period leading up to the member’s selected retirement date;

Transfers in from other UK schemes must be accepted without additional charges (including contracted-out benefits);

Normally when a transfer out is made to another scheme, there will not be a penalty. Penalties may apply if an individual is invested in a with-profits fund;

Members must be provided with a detailed statement each year.

As far as I know, there isn't a lot of defined benefit pension schemes around. Most private companies moved to defined contribution pension schemes in order to save money. Most of the defined benefit pension schemes still accepting new members are in the public sector - for example local and central government.

so are the differences between the two as literal as it seems

so i get a workplace one, you can pay extra for defined benefits and you can also get a private one on top which is probably something like a defined contribution
havent looked into all those options yet



Defined benefit pension and defined contribution pension are two different thing -

Defined benefit pension is like the old 長俸 in the Hong Kong government. You know how much money you will get in benefits when you retired - usually based on how much you earned while you were working and how long you worked for the company. Your employer has taken on the risk in your pension in this case.

Defined contribution pension is like a private pension you get from a financial institution. The only thing you know is how much money you are paying in. You do not know how much money you will get when you cashed up as it depended on market conditions. The risk in this case is with you as you make the investment choices for your own pension fund.

As I said in my earlier post, many private companies are now moving towards defined contribution pension in order to save money.

Just put in a letter in your visa application to explain that you did not have your BN(O) passport at the TB test stage, but now wishes to use your BN(O) passport to apply for an UK Tier 2 visa.

Remember do not send your HKSAR passport with your Tier 2 visa application.

Also - use your BN(O) to apply for Indefinite Leave to Remain (ILR) when you are able to. A year after getting ILR, you can apply for registration for British Citizenship using for B(OTA).

https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/application-to-register-as-a-british-citizen-form-bota

Do not go back to Hong Kong for good until you get British Citizenship as the Home Office will revoke your ILR status if you stayed outside of the UK for more than 2 years.

Wish you the best of luck.

上次見board　背q左個pathway

1. unofficial chat
2. find help/ assign mentor
3. give warning
4. collect evidence. documentation
5. official meeting w/ minutes, staff w/ representation. 3month improvement plan
6. fail -> same but with HR involved
7. rinse and repeat
8. Tribunal decision -> reassign or termination

As a British Citizen coming back to the UK to settle, you can get free National Health Service (NHS) as soon as you are here. You will only need to pay for prescription (fixed at £8.60 per item), dental treatment and eye test. (Please note that prescription is free in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland).

You will only be able to get welfare benefit once you satisfy the habitual residence test. You will need to live in the UK for at lease 3 months before you meet the habitual residence test.

Once you are in the UK, go and get a National Insurance (NI) number. NI number is like the US Social Security number. Please see link below for details -

https://www.gov.uk/apply-national-insurance-number

You may also want to open an UK bank account in Hong Kong before coming to the UK for peace of mind. Both HSBC and the Bank of East Asia offer this service -

https://www.hsbc.com.hk/personal/hsbc-premier/features/premier-overseas-account.html

https://www.hkbea.com/html/en/bea-international-services-services.html

Your wife can apply for a working holiday visa and switch to the Tier 2 (General) dependent visa in the UK. If she has British National (Overseas) passport and she is under 31 years old, she can get a Tier 5 visa without too much difficulties. If she only holds a HKSAR passport, she cannot apply for an UK Tier 5 visa until next year when the COS process starts again. Please note that she cannot switch from a visitor visa (or stamp by an UK immigration officer) to a Tier 2 dependent inside the UK.

https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/603815/PBS_dependent_guidance_Jan_2017.pdf

Have a look at the above - especially pages 13 and 14.

More information in this link below -

https://www.gov.uk/tier-2-general/family-members

I must say that I am not the best person to speak to regarding Tier 2 dependent visa application. You may want to ask your questions on Tier 2 dependent visa in one of the UK immigration forum like the one below -

http://www.expatforum.com/expats/britain-expat-forum-expats-living-uk/

Two more points -

1) If she is going to come to the UK on a Tier 2 dependent visa and she has BN(O) status, ask her to renew her BN(O) passport before the application and use her BN(O) passport to get the visa.

2) Driving - she may want to learn how to drive and pass her driving test in Hong Kong before coming over to the UK. She can exchange her Hong Kong driving licence to an UK one without test (as long as she gained the Hong Kong driving licence by a driving test in Hong Kong).

The HSBC in the US also has an international banking center. Please see link below for details -

https://www.us.hsbc.com/1/2/home/personal-banking/global-banking/international-banking-center

One more point - if you were born outside of the UK and received you British Citizenship via a British Citizen parent, then you are likely to be a British Citizen by descent. A British Citizen by descent cannot automatically pass on his British Citizenship to his child born outside of the UK.

巴打本身係bc?? 係咪可以自己申請 唔經employer? 同埋洗唔洗cos


Your wife can apply for a working holiday visa and switch to the Tier 2 (General) dependent visa in the UK. If she has British National (Overseas) passport and she is under 31 years old, she can get a Tier 5 visa without too much difficulties. If she only holds a HKSAR passport, she cannot apply for an UK Tier 5 visa until next year when the COS process starts again. Please note that she cannot switch from a visitor visa (or stamp by an UK immigration officer) to a Tier 2 dependent inside the UK.

https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/603815/PBS_dependent_guidance_Jan_2017.pdf

Have a look at the above - especially pages 13 and 14.

More information in this link below -

https://www.gov.uk/tier-2-general/family-members

I must say that I am not the best person to speak to regarding Tier 2 dependent visa application. You may want to ask your questions on Tier 2 dependent visa in one of the UK immigration forum like the one below -

http://www.expatforum.com/expats/britain-expat-forum-expats-living-uk/

Two more points -

1) If she is going to come to the UK on a Tier 2 dependent visa and she has BN(O) status, ask her to renew her BN(O) passport before the application and use her BN(O) passport to get the visa.

2) Driving - she may want to learn how to drive and pass her driving test in Hong Kong before coming over to the UK. She can exchange her Hong Kong driving licence to an UK one without test (as long as she gained the Hong Kong driving licence by a driving test in Hong Kong).



Thank you so much HKG brother.

Shes holding BNO and will apply Tier-5 for coming first and then transfer to Tier-2 as you mentioned. But do you know if I need to inform my employer for helping her to transfer to Tier-2?


As I said above, I am not the best person to give you information on Tier 2 dependent visa. Have a look at the expat forum link I included in my earlier reply and post your questions there - people in that forum will be able to give you the answers you are looking for.

因為我問過間2 bedrooms apartment 佢話我三個人住要收貴啲租
但唔明點解2bedrooms 唔可以三個人住


This is because any house rented out to at lease three people (who are all unrelated to each other) is classed as HMO (House in multiple occupation). The landlord will need to get a HMO licence in order to rent the house out legally.

HMO licence is there to protect the tenants as HMO would required the landlord to have annual checks on the smoke alarms, electricity and gas system within the HMO property.

https://www.gov.uk/house-in-multiple-occupation-licence
